markdownRemark.html:
How can we proactively make use of adjacency in our sense-making and decision-making?

Yesterday’s post was an introduction to adjacency. Today I want to highlight instances where the lens of adjacency can be a handy tool.

Adjacency and personal sense-making

Like Danny’s reflections on their choice of dance community in Berlin, being attuned to what are the adjacent qualities of a community can help us navigate those spaces with greater judgement and wisdom. If I am really into break dance but notice that community does not include adjacent qualities that engage me, I can just enjoy it for the pursuit of that mastery without needing it to be a promising ground for deep belonging. If I am a black American, perhaps I will desire a community or space to reach a certain level of anti-racist-adjacency before I commit to it. Or, if I’m looking for deep connection and greater shared values, I might have to search wider and further for communities that have more compatible adjacencies. One personal example: I want to raise my children in a community that has a strong movement/embodiment culture, and one where the whole community supports and acknowledges the benefits of vaccines. However, in my local circumstance, I have encountered a non-trivial overlap between movement folk and anti-vaccine folk. And perhaps I will have a better handle on what conversations I need to have in those communities to figure out how fertile the ground is for me to put roots down.

Another way we can reflect on our personal circumstances through the lens of adjacency is checking in about some of the things we ‘just go along with’. Do I really like sinking beers and watching the football or am I just doing it to fit in with this crowd? Am I really excited to chant religious hymns from a tradition I don’t follow, when I just want to do some yoga? Am I just going to Sunday service because that is what everyone here does? How much are we just band-wagoning pursuits in our lives, when we could be better served by uncovering what really interests us? This is the curse of availability; we can limit ourselves by filling our life up with what is within our easy grasp.

Common adjacencies: when stereotypes ring true

How often are yoga teachers also vegan? Or interested in new-age spirituality? Or fascinated by astrological star signs and the like? How often are “tech bros” into cross-fit, rock-climbing and craft beer? Tired stereotypes like these are both rubbish and partially true; There are many cases where someone liking one thing also has a higher chance than normal of liking a cluster of adjacent interests. If you’ve seen the “starter-pack” memes, they work on the basis of calling out these adjacencies. Once this clustering begins in a community, organization or entire culture, it can be self-reinforcing, due to the social bandwagoning and the curse of availability. But how do these clusters form in the first place? A random happenstance, reinforced by social pressure over time? Are there some deeper connective patterns linking things, for example, between coding and rock-climbing? Why isn’t it coding and playing the kazoo? Is something connecting being vegan and astrology? Or are there idealized narratives a “startup hacker” or “conscious embodied yogi” that knit together different, at times, conceptually unrelated pursuits? There are many ways to answer or explore these sorts of questions and… I won’t be doing so today :) Moving on!
